name: 02-Data-Prep-and-Feature-Building
content:
Data Preparation and Feature Building -


﻿Data Description:

This dataset corresponds to invoice-level transactions along with master data such as Vendors, Approvers, Bank Accounts, and Items. The classification and anomaly detection goal is to predict whether a transaction is fraudulent (anomaly) or genuine. The dataset comprises of the following:

  • Invoice Transactions Dataset – Core invoice and billing details.
  • Vendor Information – Vendor identifiers, concentration, and linked accounts.
  • Approver Information – Approver patterns across invoices.
  • Bank Information – Vendor–bank account linkages.
  • Item/Service Information – Quantities, prices, and contract details.


﻿Data Preparation:

The above datasets undergo multiple transformations to compute features and target labels. The following key features are engineered during the process:

  • Gaps & Ratios:
  • qty_gap, qty_gap_ratio → Difference and ratio of billed vs. received quantity.
  • hours_gap, hours_gap_ratio → Difference and ratio of billed vs. logged hours.
  • Price & Amount Checks:
  • price_gap, price_ratio → Difference between billed unit price and contract price.
  • amount_minus_expected → Billed amount vs. expected amount.
  • Behavioral Indicators:
  • is_weekend_invoice, invoice_day, invoice_hour → Detect weekend/odd-hour invoices.
  • vendor_day_invoice_count → Frequency of invoices per vendor per day.
  • dup_combo_count → Duplicate detection based on vendor/customer/amount.
  • Control Metrics:
  • bank_vendor_count → Number of vendors linked to the same bank account.
  • approver_vendor_count → Number of vendors associated with an approver.
  • item_vendor_count → Concentration of vendors linked to an item/service.
  • Derived Fields:
  • amount_per_unit → Per-unit billing consistency.
  • Anomaly label (isolated_prediction) from Isolation Forest (< 6 = anomaly, ≥ 6 = good).

The combination of these features, along with SHAP values, enables explainable fraud detection by capturing overbilling patterns, ghost hours, price inflation, duplicate invoices, vendor collusion, and unusual transaction behaviors.
